did.abstract: The papers of German born illustrator and children's book author Hans Wilhelm. The papers consist of dummies, illustrations, books (4), works of art, preliminary sketches, photographs, fliers, posters, ephemera (calendars), and postcards related to Wilhelm's book, "Hello Sun!"

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Hans Wilhelm was born in Bremen, Germany shortly after the end of the second World War. He later attended art and business school in Germany before moving to South Africa where he began his career in illustrating, writing, and art. Wilhelm traveled throughout the world before finally settling in the United States, at which point he began to write and illustrate hundreds of children's books. Wilhelm has written several series of popular children's books, to include those about the soccer playing bunny, Ralph, the vulnerable dinosaur, Boland, and the mean spirited Tyrone, from whom he teaches children solutions to the problem of being bullied. In addition to writing his books Wilhelm also illustrates his stories, many of which have been translated into dozens of foreign languages. When not writing Wilhelm can often be found visiting schools and libraries, showing children how he writes his books, sharing new stories, and helping children write and illustrate their own stories. Hans Wilhelm lives in Westport, Connecticut.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of dummies, illustrations, books (4), works of art, preliminary sketches, photographs, fliers, posters, ephemera (calendars), and postcards related to Hans Wilhelm's book Hello Sun! These include original illustrations for the design of the dust jacket, sketches of individual pages of the book, color proofs of the book, and photographs used to sketch illustrations for the book. The papers were donated to become a part of the Northeast Children's Literature Collection at the Dodd Center.

Hans Wilhelm also donated a significant number of his books in many different languages. Over 200 were digitized to be included in the International Children's Digital Library (http://en.childrenslibrary.org/).
